can you share a little bit

How has it been so far?
- Sure.
Yeah, so it's been certainly interesting.

So, in general with when you
have something like content,

for us, we're always interested
in the latest technologies
that let us handle sort of at scale,

So in general, for most of our customers,

like 90% of the data they

And so many companies consider this
some of their most valuable information,
but it kind of sometimes gets,

it's difficult to manage in
terms of getting the information

you need when you want
it because historically

what you had to do is
have a human sit down
and kind of read through it, right?

If you wanted to know about
some information in a document,
you read it.

If you wanna know about
a video, you watch it.
Like, and that kind of of stuff.

So whereas there's been this
like giant data revolution

with structured data,
like stuff in databases,

there wasn't necessarily
the same revolution
that happened with unstructured data.

And so we've been very
interested in the history of AI

around using techniques to let
us kind of gather insights,
and for many years we've done that.

We've used some AWS technologies,
things like Textract,
things like some of your SageMaker,
like machine learning capabilities
to kind of understand the data.

But to be honest, for
many years it was kind of,

you know, it worked well

both in the type and the
reason for it, that it was,

you never kind of had
anything that really sort of
was like a brand new set of technologies

But when generative AI came
out, and in particular,

when it kind of got to
the level of sort of

like what you would call
like maybe two years ago,
like GPT-3.0 level kind of of style,

that's when really the
capabilities of being able

to be like an AI assistant,
who could go through

the way that humans would,

understand, extract
insights from your data,

and this is what, when we talk
to our enterprise customers,
they're very excited about.
Because basically this huge corpus

of very useful information
suddenly becomes more useful

you know, again, a person to
do every little piece of it.

You can have the technology
kind of really assist you.

Can you share a little bit
about how the AI assistant,

the Box AI assistant,
what are the benefits

I as a customer get

- Yeah, so there's kind
of, there's a whole variety

but two of the most important

that our customers tell us
about is this idea of being able

to sort of ask questions
around a corpus of data
and kind of get responses.
So imagine that you had, I'll just,
there's plenty of examples and content,

like a sales portal of information of,

so like your salesperson, your
job is to kind of understand,
you know, get trained on all this data

and your job is to kind
of sell to customers.

And so imagine, but like
many of our customers
have complex products of all types,
all industries and so on.
And so you might go and say, like,
so a customer asks you a question like,
"Oh, how does this thing work?"
Or, "What is this certification or what,"
like something that is typically complex,

domain-specific, company-specific
type of information.
So, you know, a lot of times historically,
"Oh, let me get back to you.
"Let me check with Sales in Europe."

But now, with the idea of
something like the feature
of like what we'd call multi-document QA
or we have a feature called Hubs AI,

using the power of generative
AI in these models,

you can actually ask
this corpus of content,

you basically ask an assistant
to look through it for you
and get an answer in real time.

So you can imagine like your
customer asks a question

and you can ask it, and
then it comes back to you
and says, "Well, here's the information."

And it looked it up in the
information that was available,
you know, that your team makes,

that your product marketing
or your engineers,
they put the information in here

and the different forms of
different sort of modalities,

and then the AI can kind
of synthesize it all

and give you not, "Here's
a document to read

"to answer this question,
but here's the answer

"that I've gathered from
all this information."
So this is something that uses

retrieval-augmented
generation, and it uses sort of

the underlying AI tech to be
able to get you this data.

And this is one really
critical thing that we think

is going to be sort of not
only like a big difference

from people, how people
used to use their content,
but just incredibly useful.
And the second sort of key use case for us

is this idea of sometimes
you have a lot of data
that has like a structured element to it.

Typically things like
business process documents,
like contracts or invoices or policies

or these kind of whole corpus
of data that has, like,
like the idea of the structure and labels

And so this is something that in the past

the older school machine
learning techniques

to be able to like kind
of have a model trained

to do one thing, but with
the power of generative AI,
it can kind of label a structured data
in many different ways.

So you can imagine you

and you have AI go through

some really critical

standard operating
procedures or contracts.
So the AI can go through, read it,

and then just pull out the
key info that your teams need

to be able to sort of
manage that kind of data.

So generative AI is excellent
at that kind of thing.

like there's kind of two important things.
One is quality and then one is trust.

like, our enterprise

new capabilities with AI,

to basically just say,

And so for us, for AWS,

They have sort of seen that the AWS

if you're a lawyer and you have questions
